content.text:
After defeating the Shadow Beast, you find a dusty tome glowing with strange runes. The guild master whispers:
"This is the Great Codex. Inside are secrets of every monster ‚Äî their health, their weaknesses, their favorite snacks‚Ä¶ all stored in magical pairs."

In Python, this magic is called a dictionary. It stores key‚Äìvalue pairs: each key (like ‚ÄúGoblin‚Äù) points to a value (like ‚Äúweak to fire‚Äù). Unlike lists (which store items in order), dictionaries are like magical lookup tables: ask the book about a monster, and it whispers its weakness.
Your mission this week: master the Monster Codex.
Tags Introduced

items: DictBasics ‚Üí what dictionaries are and how to create them.
DictAccess ‚Üí looking up monster info by key.
DictMutate ‚Üí adding, changing, and removing entries.
DictIterate ‚Üí looping through monsters and their stats.

content.text: Concept Notes

items: Each entry has a key and a value, joined with a colon :.
Multiple entries are separated by commas.
Keys must be unique (you can‚Äôt have two different Goblins).

content.text:
codex = {"Goblin": "fire", "Skeleton": "light", "Slime": "salt"}
print(codex)
üëâ RPG Connection: Think of a dictionary as a magic book. Each monster‚Äôs name is a key; its weakness is the value written in invisible ink.
Hero Training Drill 1 ‚Äì First Entries in the Codex üìñ
‚úÖ Solution

codex = {"Dragon": "ice", "Zombie": "light"}
print(codex)
üëÄ The book glows: ‚ÄúKnowledge is power‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt forget it.‚Äù
Concept Notes

items: To look up a value, use the key inside square brackets [].
If the key doesn‚Äôt exist, Python throws an error (like flipping to a blank page).

content.text:
codex = {"Goblin": "fire", "Skeleton": "light"}
print(codex["Goblin"])  # fire
üëâ RPG Connection: This is like asking the book: ‚ÄúCodex, how do I beat a Goblin?‚Äù
Hero Training Drill 2 ‚Äì Discover a Weakness üîé

Mission Briefing:
"Quick! A Skeleton attacks. Find its weakness in my pages!"
‚úÖ Solution

codex = {"Dragon": "ice", "Zombie": "light", "Skeleton": "fire"}
print("Skeleton is weak to:", codex["Skeleton"])
üëÄ Skeleton: ‚ÄúAw man, why‚Äôd they write that down?!‚Äù
Concept Notes

codex = {"Goblin": "fire"}

codex["Slime"] = "salt"      # add
codex["Goblin"] = "sunlight" # change
del codex["Goblin"]          # remove

print(codex)
üëâ RPG Connection: Updating the Codex = discovering new weaknesses or crossing out old myths.
Hero Training Drill 3 ‚Äì Updating the Codex ‚úçÔ∏è
‚úÖ Solution

codex = {"Dragon": "ice", "Zombie": "light"}

codex["Slime"] = "salt"
codex["Zombie"] = "holy water"
del codex["Dragon"]

print(codex)
üëÄ Codex whispers: ‚ÄúThe truth evolves. Only fools trust old myths.‚Äù
Concept Notes
Looping through a dictionary reveals monsters and their weaknesses. Use .items() to get both key and value.
üëâ RPG Connection: This is like reading the Codex aloud in the guild hall so everyone learns monster secrets.
Hero Training Drill 4 ‚Äì Read the Codex Aloud üìú
Mission Briefing: Speak every entry from the Codex.
‚úÖ Solution
üëÄ Villager: ‚ÄúA slime weak to salt? So my French fries could defeat it?!‚Äù
üéØ Challenge Quest ‚Äì Monster Codex Trial

items: You enter a chamber filled with monster statues. The Codex glows:
"Hero, if you cannot master my pages, the statues will awaken‚Ä¶ and eat you."

content.text: Tasks

items: Loop through the Codex, announcing each weakness.

content.text: ‚úÖ Solution

codex = {"Orc": "lightning", "Vampire": "sunlight", "Troll": "fire"}

print("Vampire is weak to:", codex["Vampire"])

codex["Werewolf"] = "silver"
codex["Troll"] = "ice"
del codex["Orc"]

for monster, weakness in codex.items():
    print(monster, "is weak to", weakness)
üëÄ Codex roars: ‚ÄúYou have passed the trial. My secrets are yours‚Ä¶ but beware ‚Äî knowledge attracts darker forces.‚Äù
üéâ By the end of Week 10
Their hero now owns the Monster Codex, a magical book that reveals enemy weaknesses mid-battle.

üëâ Next week: Chapter 11 ‚Äì Tuples & Sets in the Wild (Strange Relics). On the path forward, you‚Äôll discover relics that can‚Äôt be changed (tuples) and unique treasures no two heroes can share (sets).
üìñ Codex Copy Room ‚Äî Pip writes monster weaknesses as key‚Äìvalue pairs.

codex = {"Goblin": "fire", "Skeleton": "light"}
print(codex)

items: 1) Make codex with Dragon‚Üíice and Zombie‚Üílight; print it.

content.text: Section: Dict Access
üîé Weakness Lookup ‚Äî Professor Glyph asks the Codex a question.

items: Use square brackets with a key: codex["Goblin"]
If the key doesn‚Äôt exist, Python raises an error.

content.text:
codex = {"Skeleton": "fire"}
print(codex["Skeleton"])  # fire
Section: Dict Mutate
‚úçÔ∏è Updating Pages ‚Äî add, change, and remove entries as myths evolve.

codex = {"Goblin": "fire"}
codex["Slime"] = "salt"
codex["Goblin"] = "sunlight"
del codex["Goblin"]
print(codex)

items:
‚úÖ Solution:
codex={"Dragon":"ice"}
codex["Troll"]="fire"
del codex["Dragon"]
print(codex)

content.text: Section: Dict Iterate
üì£ Guild Reading ‚Äî announce every monster and weakness using a loop.

items: Use .items() to loop over (key, value) pairs.

content.text: Section: Boss Challenge
üóùÔ∏è Boss Challenge ‚Äî Full Monster Codex Trial

items: Loop through codex and announce each weakness.

content.text:
codex = {"Orc": "lightning", "Vampire": "sunlight", "Troll": "fire"}
print("Vampire is weak to:", codex["Vampire"])

codex["Werewolf"] = "silver"
codex["Troll"] = "ice"
del codex["Orc"]

for monster, weakness in codex.items():
    print(monster, "is weak to", weakness)
